intervention_description: Informed participants that previous research had found that people who consume more meat endorse hierarchy and dominance values, whereas people who consume more fruits and vegetables reject hierarchy and dominance values.

Participants received a presentation on declining meat consumption trends in Canada since 1980 and the negative health, animal welfare, and environmental impacts of meat consumption (including PETA videos). They completed a mind attribution task writing about a cow's thoughts and feelings, received practical tips for planning meat-free meals and making substitutions, and set a monthly goal to reduce, maintain, or increase their meat consumption. Text messages provided ongoing reinforcement with educational information, benefit reminders, and recipe links., Text-messaging reinforcement of the informational and self-monitoring components. The messages sent upbeat and educational information that reminded participants of the benefits of reducing meat consumption and provided them with additional tips and links to recipes.
intervention_mechanism: factual, negative emotional, perspective taking, goal pursuit, norms

intervention_description: Participants watched a video about pigs in animal agriculture on a tablet.
control_description: Control participants were not exposed to a video, but it was not a truly neutral control condition, in that the canopy used for the study was covered in graphic images of farm animals

intervention_description: Participants watched a 360 degrees video about pigs in animal agriculture. They wore Samsung headsets, which allow viewers to pan in any direction for the duration of each frame.
control_description: Control participants were not exposed to a video, but it was not a truly neutral control condition, in that the canopy used for the study was covered in graphic images of farm animals

intervention_description: Humane farm description of the ham sampled by participants: "This ham was raised on a farm that focused on animal welfare. The animals were allowed to roam in grassy outdoor pastures where they could graze and exercise. The animals were not isolated so were able to engage in social behaviors with other pigs."

Factory farm description for the ham sampled by participants: "This ham was produced at a factory farm that focused on production. The animals were confined to concrete indoor pens where they were unable to lie down or go outside. The animals were isolated so could not engage in social behaviors with other pigs."
Facebook posts showing what farmed animals endure in factory farms. Promotion-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan saves 200 animals per year").
Facebook posts showing what farmed animals endure in factory farms. Prevention-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan prevents 270 animals per year from being killed").
Facebook posts showing the special characteristics of animals presented as unique individuals. Promotion-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan saves 200 animals per year").
intervention_mechanism: negative emotional, goal pursuit, perspective taking

intervention_description: Facebook posts showing the special characteristics of animals presented as unique individuals. Prevention-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan prevents 270 animals per year from being killed").
intervention_mechanism: negative emotional, goal pursuit, perspective taking

intervention_description: Participants watched the "Lisa the vegetarian" Simpson's episode.
intervention_mechanism: infotainment, origin of animal product, authority/expertise

intervention_description: Participants received a daily email to remind them of their goal to monitor their red meat consumption and not exceed 200g per week.
Participants received a daily text message via WhatsApp focused on anticipated regret that urged participants to self-monitor processed meat consumption.
Booklet focusing primarily on cruelty, discussing all farm animals, and why to go vegetarian.

intervention_description: Participants watched a 7-minute video that informed viewers of the negative health effects of high meat consumption (high threat) and suggested easy ways to reduce their meat consumption to increase perceived efficacy.

Participants watched a 4-minute video containing the same information about the negative health effects of high meat consumption (high threat) along with the recommended action to eat less meat, but it only included a very minor efficacy component in the conclusion.
Participants received a leaflet "​Maak het Verschil"​, a Dutch translation of a highly popular leaflet distributed by Vegan Outreach, Compassionate Choices.
intervention_mechanism: positive emotional, negative emotional, origin of animal product, norms, factual, goal pursuit

intervention_description: Participants read a text providing information about meat consumption, adressing environmental consequences of meat consumption and other arguments for reduced consumption.

Participants read a text providing information about meat consumption, adressing environmental consequences of meat consumption and other arguments for reduced consumption. Participants completed a procedure for mental contrasting with implementation intentions in which individuals wrote down (1) a personal goal, (2) positive outcomes of goal achievement, the best outcome, and respective associations, (3) obstacles of goal achievement, their two main obstacles, and respective associations, and finally (4) four IIs addressing their two main obstacles.
Participants watched "Babe: The gallant pig", a movie about a pig who wants to become a sheepdog.
control_description: Participants for the control group were recruited via the Facebook events of the movie screenings with a message that encouraged anybody who couldn’t attend the screenings but still wanted to join the experiment to fill in the survey.

intervention_description: Participants watched "The Ghost in Our Machine", a movie about the animal rights activist and photographer Jo-Ann McArthur.
control_description: Participants for the control group were recruited via the Facebook events of the movie screenings with a message that encouraged anybody who couldn’t attend the screenings but still wanted to join the experiment to fill in the survey.

control_description: Participants read a neutral essay about the 1980 Winter Olympics.

control_description: Participants watched a slideshow on the 1980 Winter Olympics.

intervention_description: Participants watched a slideshow that included images and short paragraphs of animal welfare concerns related to meat.

intervention_description: Partcipants saw the message: "Recent research has shown that, in the last 5 years, 30% of Americans have now started to make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that, in recent years, 3 in 10 people have changed their behavior and begun to eat less meat than they otherwise would."
Partcipants saw the message: "Recent research has shown that 30% of Americans make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that 3 in 10 people eat less meat than they otherwise would."

Partcipants saw the message: "Some people are starting to limit how much meat they eat. This is true both nationally and here at Stanford. Specifically, recent research has shown that, over the last 5 years, 30% of Americans have started to make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that, in recent years, 3 in 10 people have changed their behavior and begun to eat less meat than they otherwise would."

Partcipants saw the message: "Some people limit how much meat they eat. This is true both nationally and here at Stanford. Specifically, recent research has shown that 30% of Americans make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that 3 in 10 people eat less meat than they otherwise would."
Participants saw a photo of a cow with a short statement saying that the cow will be sent to the abattoir tomorrow.
Participants saw a photo of a cow with a short statement saying that the cow will be sent to the abattoir tomorrow.
Participants saw a beef dish recipe in a short text with a photo of a cow, illustrating the source of beef in the dish.
Participants saw a beef dish recipe in a short text with a photo of a cow, illustrating the source of beef in the dish.
Participants saw an advertisement for lamb chops including the picture of a cute lamb.
intervention_mechanism: positive emotional, origin of animal product
control_description: Participants saw an advertisement for lamb chops.

intervention_description: Participants attended a presentation that documents the abuse on factory farms, is pro animal, and asked students to reduce or eliminate animal meat and products from their diets. Focus was mainly on the ethical implications of factory farming, and also touched on health and environmental consequences.
control_description: Participants from a different class that did not attend the presentation.

intervention_description: Participants were offered and took one of two Vegan Outreach: "Compassionate Choices" or "Even If You Like Meat".
intervention_mechanism: factual, origin of animal product, negative emotional
control_description: Participants were offered and took a control flyer on puppy mills called "The Cruelty Behind Cuteness"

intervention_description: Participants read a pork policy article that discusses the policy commitments of major companies to transition the pigs in their supply chains from gestation crates to crate-free environments.
control_description: Participants read a policy article that discusses the policy commitments of major companies to transition from plastic bags to paper bags.

intervention_description: Participants read a pork legislation article that discusses the legislation implemented by many U.S. states banning the use of gestation crates.
control_description: Participants read a legislation article that discusses the legislation implemented by many U.S. states banning the use of plastic bags.

intervention_description: Participants saw a pro-vegetarian Facebook and that, after clicking on it, directed them to a Mercy for Animals landing page with a video on cruelty to farm animals called Farm to Fridge.
control_description: Participants saw a pro-vegetarian Facebook and that, after clicking on it, directed them to a Mercy for Animals landing page with a video on fighting tropical diseases.

intervention_description: Participants read James Rachels' article “The Basic Argument for Vegetarianism” and were also encouraged to view, on their own outside of class, an optional eleven-minute vegetarianism advocacy video “What Came Before”.
control_description: Participants read Peter Singer's article “The Singer Solution to World Poverty” and were encouraged to view, on their own outside of class, an optional nineteen-minute video advocating donation to hunger-relief initiatives: “Ending Hunger Now”.

intervention_description: Participants watched a 20-min documentary entitled "Good For Us", which encourages plant-based diets that reduce consumption of all meats and animal products. Each segment was followed by free-response questions about the content presented. After the documentary, participants were asked whether they would like to pledge to reduce their consumption, pledge to eliminate their consumption, or to make no pledge. For participants who had chosen to make at least one “reduce” or “eliminate” pledge, several items designed to improve general and specific goal-setting and self-monitoring were presented. One week after the baseline measurement, a customized reminder email was sent to pledge-making participants.
intervention_mechanism: factual, negative emotional, norms, origin of animal product, goal pursuit
control_description: Participants watched a 20-min TED talk by Brené Brown entitled “Listening to shame”, a generic motivational speech that encouraged listeners to embrace the experience of feeling vulnerable.

intervention_description: Participants watched a 20-min documentary entitled "Good For Us", which encourages plant-based diets that reduce consumption of all meats and animal products. For participants who had chosen to make at least one “reduce” or “eliminate” pledge, several items designed to improve general and specific goal-setting and self-monitoring were presented. One week after the baseline measurement, a customized reminder email was sent to pledge-making participants.

After the documentary, participants were asked whether they would like to pledge to reduce their consumption, pledge to eliminate their consumption, or to make no pledge. intervention_description: The digital menu included the message “Many here choose green!” next to the "green food category", which was accompanied by a minimalistic illustration of three people.
The icon representing the “green” food category was moved from the sixth position in the grid of icons in the digital menu (out of 10) to the first position.
The digital menu included the message  “The green option feels good!” which was accompanied by a happy emoji with a halo, conveying a sense of feeling good by doing good.
The digital menu included the message “The green option tastes good!” which was accompanied by an emoji with its tongue on one side of its mouth, conveying a sense of tastiness and fun.

Participants read that "The World Health Organization (WHO) classified red meat as a possible carcinogen, meaning it could cause cancer. Based on estimates from the Global Disease Burden Project, the WHO states that >34.000 cancer deaths per year worldwide are attributable to high intake of processed meat, while the total number of deaths attributable to a diet rich in red meat was 644.000."

Participants read that "The World Health Organization (WHO) classified red meat as a possible carcinogen, meaning it could cause cancer. Just 50 g of red or processed meat consumed in a regular daily diet can increase cancer incidence by 18%. It is known that high consumption of red or processed meat can increase the risk of other chronic diseases (such as stroke and type II diabetes)."

Participants attended a moral philosophy course in which various controversial topics, including meat eating, were discussed. They read Alastair Norcross' Puppies, Pigs, and People. Participants were also instructed to reflect on their views as an additional manipulation.
Participants attended a moral philosophy course in which various controversial topics, including meat eating, were discussed. They read Alastair Norcross' Puppies, Pigs, and People.

Participants received daily persuasive messages that cited the health and environmental outcomes of red processed meat cosumption. The information was presented in a way that was meant to evoke anticipated regret (e.g., “If you eat an excessive amount of red/processed meat, you could feel regret for not protecting your health from cancer and the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases”).
control_description: Participants received daily persuasive messages describing the health and environmental consequences of eating sugar.

intervention_description: Participants received daily persuasive messages that cited the health and environmental outcomes of red processed meat cosumption.
control_description: Participants received daily persuasive messages describing the health and environmental consequences of eating sugar.

intervention_description: Participants saw a menu of 34 items divided into four categories (appetizers, entrees, “design your own bowl”, and salads), with text at the top of the menu reading, “Sustainability Rankings at the [name of café]". The leaf rating that accompanies each menu item represented the sustainability of each item.
control_description: Participants saw a menu of 34 items divided into four categories (appetizers, entrees, “design your own bowl”, and salads).

intervention_description: Participants saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Sustainable Choice.” The text on this screen read, “Many people don’t know how much our food choices impact the environment. Eating sustainable foods is a good way we can fight climate change! The Garden Fresh Veggie Burger is an especially sustainable choice. Consider giving the Garden Fresh Veggie Burger a try today!”

Participants saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Student Choice.” The text on the screen read, “The garden fresh veggie burger is a tasty choice! In a taste test we did at the [name of caf´e], 95% of people said that the veggie burger tasted good or very good! Consider giving the garden fresh veggie burger a try today!”

Participants saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Student Choice.” The text on the screen read, “The garden fresh veggie burger is a tasty choice! In a taste test we did at the [name of caf´e], 95% of people said that the veggie burger tasted good or very good! Consider giving the garden fresh veggie burger a try today!”. They also saw a screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label, “Sustainable Choice.” The text on this screen read, “Many people don’t know how much our food choices impact the environment. Eating sustainable foods is a good way we can fight climate change! The Garden Fresh Veggie Burger is an especially sustainable choice. Consider giving the Garden Fresh Veggie Burger a try today!”.

Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Climatarian diet significantly reducing or eliminating red meat from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Livestock agriculture contributes up to a quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions, with almost all of this coming from cows and sheep. In Australia, producing 1 kg of beef requires an average of 15,182 L of water. Furthermore, livestock agriculture drives 80% of deforestation worldwide, using up a third of the world s ice-free land. Adopting a Climatarian diet is a powerfulway to reduce your impact on the climate. Shifting to a Climatarian diet will reduce your carbon footprint by approximately 1000 kg of CO2 every year, or the equivalent of driving from Perth to Brisbane."

Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is the ‘One step for the animals diet' eliminating chicken from our diets. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. The vast majorityof these animals today are birds. It takes more than 200 chickens to provide the same number of meals as one cow.If we can convince someone to stop eating birds, they would go from being responsible for the factory farming and slaughtering of more than two dozen land animals per year to fewer than one. Furthermore, while most cows and sheep raised in Australia spend most of their life grazing, the vast majority of chickens are raised in crowded factory farms."

Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Reducetarian diet reducing the amount of meat that we eat. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factoryfarms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a reductionist diet is appealing because not everyone is willing to follow an all-or-nothing diet. It is also a powerful way to reduce animal cruelty. For example, halving your meat consumption will spare around 50 innocent lives every year. This includes about 13 land animals, and 37 fish and shellfish every year."

Participants read:  "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Vegetarian diet eliminating all meat and fish from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a vegetarian diet is the most powerful way to object to animal cruelty, and by doing so, you will spare approximately 100 animal lives (25 land animals and 75 fish and shellfish) every year."

Participants were invited to take part in a 28-day commitment to eat meat-free and they were given the opportunity to freely opt out of the pledge, by withdrawing from the study, or continue with it, by offering their written consent. Participants were encouraged to “do their best” to try to eat meat-free for the duration of the study.

Participants were invited to take part in a 28-day commitment to eat meat-free and they were given the opportunity to freely opt out of the pledge, by withdrawing from the study, or continue with it, by offering their written consent. Participants were encouraged to “do their best” to try to eat meat-free for the duration of the study.

Participants were invited to take part in a 28-day commitment to eat meat-free and they were given the opportunity to freely opt out of the pledge, by withdrawing from the study, or continue with it, by offering their written consent. Participants were encouraged to “do their best” to try to eat meat-free for the duration of the study.

Participants read James Rachels’ article “The Basic Argument for Vegetarianism”. Teaching assistants played the 11-minute vegetarianism advocacy video “What Came Before” that contained factory farm footage. They also presented both pro and con considerations in their discussion sections, encouraging debate among students.
intervention_mechanism: negative emotional, factual, origin of animal product

intervention_description: Participants read James Rachels’ article “The Basic Argument for Vegetarianism”. Teaching assistants presented both pro and con considerations in their discussion sections, encouraging debate among students.
intervention_mechanism: negative emotional, factual, origin of animal product

intervention_description: Participants read a brief paragraph that highlighted the connections between zoonotic diseases and factory farming.
control_description: Participants read a brief paragraphon geocaching.

intervention_description: Participants read a brief paragraph that highlighted the connections between animal cruelty and factory farming.
control_description: Participants read a brief paragraphon geocaching.

intervention_description: A vegetarian dish was listed as the first item on the menu and was also made visible to customers at the counter
control_description: A meat dish was listed as the first item on the menu and was also made visible to customers at the counter., A meat dish was listed as the first item on the menu and was also made visible to customers at the counter

intervention_description: A vegetarian dish was listed as the first item on the menu.
control_description: A meat dish was listed as the first item on the menu.

intervention_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of 10 values and briefly describe a situation or example that shows how the first-ranked value is reflected in their personal experience. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.
control_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of their favorite colors and explained how this color is personally appealing, e.g., to describe an object or context in which it was appealing. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.

intervention_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of 10 values and briefly describe a situation or example that shows how the first-ranked value is reflected in their group experience. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.
control_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of their favorite colors and explained how this color is personally appealing, e.g., to describe an object or context in which it was appealing. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.

intervention_description: "Chef’s recommendation" stickers were placed on the vegetarian sandwich bags. One vegetarian sandwich was displayed on a plate at eye-level with the content clearly visible. This plate was accompanied by a sign that read “Kokken anbefaler” (Chef's recommendation) and a brief description of the café’s sustainability goals. All vegetarian sandwiches were placed in first line-of-sight from the typical customer flow direction. The labels on vegetarian sandwiches were slightly more colourful and the bags were closed more aesthetically than meat sandwiches.

A 2-day workshop with the canteen kitchen staff on the relevance of promoting plant-based eating, basic principles of plant-based nutritional literacy, and practical demonstrations of how to improve the visual and sensory appeal of plant-based meals was conducted. Posters advertising the "Sustainability Week" initiative were placed in the cafeteria. The menu presented the vegetarian option as the "suggestion of the day" with an increased font size above the meat and fish options.
Students passed by a vegetarian option first the cafeteria.
control_description: Students passed by a meat option first when entering the cafeteria.

intervention_description: Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.
control_description: Students passed by a meat option first when entering the cafeteria.

intervention_description: Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.
control_description: Students passed by a meat option first when entering the cafeteria.

intervention_description: Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.
control_description: Students passed by a meat option first when entering the cafeteria.

intervention_description: Students passed by a vegetarian option first when entering the cafeteria.
control_description: Students passed by a meat option first when entering the cafeteria.

intervention_description: Participants completed a 12-week compassion and cating-based training which consisted of weekly sessions á 75 min and weekly homework assignments. Participants were introduced to a way to offer love to themselves, other people, or animals. Affect dyad situations were applied where partners sit face to face, and one partner contemplates a situation to a specific theme of the main topics. The other partner listens attentively without giving any verbal or non-verbal feedback.

Participants completed a 12-week mindfulness-based stress reduction program that included various elements of meditation: body scan, mindful eating, emphasizing the breath, and sitting and walking meditation training. Every session contained a talk about specific topics such as different forms of meditation and problems that may arise with them. The focus of this mindfulness group was on the rather cognitive elements of mindfulness and its qualities of awareness.

With a visible timer counting down from 3 min, participants were asked to recall 10 behaviors where they acted “particularly masculine/manly” or “particularly feminine/womanly” (depending on their gender). Participants read that men and women can easily recall 12 behaviors. The task is intentionally difficult with the purpose of leading participants to infer that their performance is below purportedly acceptable standards for their respective gender, thus threatening gender identity. Then, participants were asked to evaluate photographic art prints that a restaurant is considering exhibiting in its dining areas: participants viewed a slideshow consisting of 15 pretested stock photographs portraying scenes of vulnerability, human connection, care-giving, and displays of emotional distress. The photos pictured female and male adults, as well as children and the elderly, and a range of ethnicities.
control_description: With a visible timer counting down from 3 min, participants were asked to recall 10 behaviors where they acted “particularly masculine/manly” or “particularly feminine/womanly” (depending on their gender). Participants read that men and women can easily recall 12 behaviors. The task is intentionally difficult with the purpose of leading participants to infer that their performance is below purportedly acceptable standards for their respective gender, thus threatening gender identity. Then, participants were asked to evaluate photographic art prints that a restaurant is considering exhibiting in its dining areas: participants viewed a slideshow consisting of geometric shapes.

intervention_description: Installation of of visual manipulations under the guise of a photo exhibit at the restaurant. The photographic stimuli were chosen with the following in mind: the connection between human and animal needed to be emphasized by visual overlap between the subjects, suggesting a caring, devoted, and protecting attitude.

All participants completed an essay task that threatened gender identity and subsequently watched a slideshow. Compassion was primed a slideshow using photographs showing people as having a caring, devoted, and protecting attitude. Participants then reviewed ingredients and nutritional information for the BLT, chicken, and falafel wrap presented in standard FDA tables.
control_description: All participants completed an essay task that threatened gender identity and subsequently watched a slideshow. Participants were presented with a slideshow of geometric shapes. Participants then reviewed ingredients and nutritional information for the BLT, chicken, and falafel wrap presented in standard FDA tables.

intervention_description: Signs with a Planetary Health Plate graphic featuring a diet based on the EAT Lancet Planetary Health Diet were posted. The sign included information on top of the sign: “Today, our diets have a large impact on our global ecosystem. In February 2019, scientists collaborated with The Lancet medical journal to establish this realistic diet that maintains both human and planetary health.” And on the bottom of the sign “Modeling your plate like this one builds a healthy diet and a sustainable world”.
All meat dishes were labeled as “High CO2” dishes, all fish dishes as “Medium CO2”, and all vegetarian as “Low CO2” dishes.
The vegetarian dish was labeled with the “Low CO2” sign.
The meat dish was labeled with a “High CO2” sign.
Individuals responded to an RSVP survey for an event in which the vegetarian option was the default meal preference.
control_description: Individuals responded to an RSVP survey for an event in which the meat option was the default meal preference.

intervention_description: A video (2:48 minutes long) was presented which showed a parallel world wherein the roles of humans and animals were reversed. The video presented illustrations of situations in which animals are harmed, but where the humans took the role of the animals and vice versa.

A video (2:48 minutes long) was presented which showed a parallel world wherein the roles of humans and animals were reversed. The video presented illustrations of situations in which animals are harmed, but where the humans took the role of the animals and vice versa.
The menu listed the daily vegetarian and fish dishes but not the meat dish and a sentence stated that “an option containing meat is available on request.”
control_description: The menu contained, as before, the daily meat and fish options for the whole week, and had an additional sentence stating that “a vegetarian option is available on request.”

intervention_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the plant-based default condition, the plant-based sausage was selected.
control_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. The baseline condition, in which pork was pre-selected, was used to reflect the real-world status quo.

intervention_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the sustainable plant-based default condition, the plant-based sausage was selected and a pop-up message said "We have selected the most sustainable sausage for you”.
control_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. The baseline condition, in which pork was pre-selected, was used to reflect the real-world status quo.

intervention_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the tasty plant-based default conditions, the plant-based sausage was selected and a pop-up message said "We have selected the tastiest sausage for you”.
control_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. The baseline condition, in which pork was pre-selected, was used to reflect the real-world status quo.

intervention_description: The intervention consisted of 4 components: 1) free meat substitutes for the household for 4 weeks; 2) information leaflets about the health and environmental benefits of eating less meat; 3) recipes; and 4) success stories in the form of vignettes of people who reduced their meat intake.

Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (e.g., "Meat harms your health"). All quotes refer to ‘‘scientific evidence’’ or a ‘‘study’’ without naming the specific source. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.
control_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article on sugary drinks at school kiosks and did not contain any reference to meat. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.

intervention_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (e.g., "A little less meat on plates would help protect the climate more than many people think."). All quotes refer to ‘‘scientific evidence’’ or a ‘‘study’’ without naming the specific source. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.
control_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article on sugary drinks at school kiosks and did not contain any reference to meat. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.

intervention_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (e.g., "All scientific findings prove that animals are social creatures, capable of suffering"). All quotes refer to ‘‘scientific evidence’’ or a ‘‘study’’ without naming the specific source. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.
control_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article on sugary drinks at school kiosks and did not contain any reference to meat. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.

intervention_description: The message “More and more [retail store name] customers are choosing our veggie options” appeared in a green circle on the top right corner of the image displayed on the digital boards, covering 1/8th of the screen, and was animated with a small stretching and wobbling effect to draw customers’ attention further. The message was displayed alongside a picture of the vegetarian breakfast option during the breakfast service hours, and a vegetarian main meal during the remaining trading hours.

Participants completed an identity manipulation: Please think of yourself as a person that cares about environmental sustainability (sustainable social identity). Please write at least 4–5 sentences (25 words) about the following topic: What are things that you and other people that care about environmental sustainability do ... often? ... rarely? ... well? ... badly?. Meal name manipulation: the vegetarian burgers were labeled as a sustainable halloumi burger and a sustainable falafel burger.
control_description: Participants completed an identity manipulation: Please think of yourself as an individual (personal identity). Please write at least 4–5 sentences (25 words) about the following topic: What are things that you personally do ... often? ... rarely? ... well? ... badly?. Meal name manipulation: the vegetarian burgers were labeled as a sustainable halloumi burger and a sustainable falafel burger.

intervention_description: Participants completed an identity manipulation: Please think of yourself as an individual (personal identity). Please write at least 4–5 sentences (25 words) about the following topic: What are things that you personally do ... often? ... rarely? ... well? ... badly?. Meal name manipulation: the vegetarian burgers were labeled as a halloumi burger and a falafel burger.
control_description: Participants completed an identity manipulation: Please think of yourself as an individual (personal identity). Please write at least 4–5 sentences (25 words) about the following topic: What are things that you personally do ... often? ... rarely? ... well? ... badly?. Meal name manipulation: the vegetarian burgers were labeled as a sustainable halloumi burger and a sustainable falafel burger.

intervention_description: A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the health condition received messages focused on the health benefits of eating little red, processed meat (e.g. “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect your health from colon cancer/heart disease/respiratory disease).

A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the environment condition participants received messages focused on the environmental benefits of eating little red, processed meat (e.g., “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases/soil acidification/climate change”).

A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the health + environment condition participants received a combination of the two messages on eating little red, processed meat (e.g., “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect your health from colon cancer/heart disease/respiratory disease, and at the same time you will protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases/soil acidification/ climate change”).
The college cafeteria decreased the price of the vegetarian option by 20 pence (from £2.05 to £1.85) and increased the price of meat options by 20 pence (from £2.52 to £2.72).
The meat option was labeled with a red “High Climate Impact” traffic light warning label
The vegetarian and vegan options were labeled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label

The meat option was labeled with a red “High Climate Impact” traffic light warning label. The vegetarian and vegan options were labeled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label. There was also an orange“Medium Climate Impact” traffic light warning label presented for the fish option.
The meat burger was labeled with a red “High Climate Impact” traffic light warning label
The vegetarian burger was labeled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label
The vegan option was labelled with a green “Low Climate Impact” traffic light warning label
The vegetarian option (veggie burger) was labeled as the dish of the day
The vegetarian option (veggie burger) was labeled as the dish of the day

Participants had an open-ended chat about meat consumption that lasted 5-10 minutes with ChatGPTT-4o. The same initial prompt was entered for all participants: “I want to have a conversation about meat consumption. I currently eat meat. Are there any reasons why I should limit my meat consumption or stop eating meat entirely?”. Participants were given a list of questions they could ask ChatGPT, but were also told that they could decide where to steer the conversation. The provided questions focused on the environment (e.g., “How does meat consumption impact the environment?”), personal health (e.g., “Is it necessary to eat meat to be healthy?”), and animal welfare (e.g., “What percentage of meat in Dutch supermarkets comes from factory farms?”), and also included more generic prompts (e.g., “It would be quite difficult to reduce my meat consumption by a lot. How can I make this easier?”).
33% of the meals offered in the cafeteria contained meat
control_description: 64% of the meals offered in the cafeteria contained meat (close to the number of meat meals offered in orevious years)

intervention_description: The vegetarian option was labeled as "our recommendation", The vegatarian option was placed at the beginning of the buffet, whereas the meat option was placed at the end
control_description: original setup in the cafeteria

intervention_description: Participants read the following information on meat consumption reduction: "Reducing one's consumption of animal products can have significant environmental benefits. For example, food-related greenhouse gas emissions can on average be lowered by about a quarter (24%) through following a vegetarian diet and by about half (53%) through following a vegan diet." before privately announced their choice of voucher
control_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room. Their choice of voucher will not be revealed to other participants. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."

intervention_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room and asked for their choice of voucher so that we can pass on the selection to the restaurant. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."
control_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room. Their choice of voucher will not be revealed to other participants. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."

intervention_description: Participants read the following information on meat consumption reduction: "Reducing one's consumption of animal products can have significant environmental benefits. For example, food-related greenhouse gas emissions can on average be lowered by about a quarter (24%) through following a vegetarian diet and by about half (53%) through following a vegan diet." before their choice of voucher was publicly announced
control_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room. Their choice of voucher will not be revealed to other participants. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."

intervention_description: Participants received dynamic norm treatment as they were provided information about decreasing meat consumption in non-specific reference groups, and about an increasing demand for vegetarian meals in the specific reference group.
control_description: Participants received unrelated trend information.

intervention_description: Customers entering the intervention store were asked the following question: “To consider a healthy and sustainable lifestyle, would you be interested in reducing your red meat purchases by one meal per week?” If customers agreed, they were asked to demonstrate their commitment by having their name listed on the public-facing project website, www.meatofthematerstudy.squarespace.com. They were also given a small business card with the project website to see their name and learn more about the study.

Participants were presented with vegetarian food box options described with indulgent words-phrases such as "soul comforting", "feel good'', ''fresh and crispy''. Meat food box options had basic descriptions in all conditions.
control_description: Participants were presented with vegetarian food box options, this condition included basic descriptions, and served as a baseline. Meat food box options had basic descriptions in all conditions.

intervention_description: Participants were presented with vegetarian food box options described with words emphasizing the healthiness (e.g. ''nutritious'', ''wholesome'', ''energy boosting''). Meat food box options had basic descriptions in all conditions.
control_description: Participants were presented with vegetarian food box options, this condition included basic descriptions, and served as a baseline. Meat food box options had basic descriptions in all conditions.

intervention_description: Participants watched a video describing the diverse benefits of plant-based eating, showed some mild factory farm footage, and described changing social norms around meat consumption to convey a growing trend. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to reduce their meat consumption.
control_description: Participants watched a video with white text on a dark background describing how to complete the study. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to reduce their meat consumption.

intervention_description: Participants watched a video describing the diverse benefits of plant-based eating, showed some mild factory farm footage, and described changing social norms around meat consumption to convey a growing trend. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to adopt a vegetarian diet.
control_description: Participants watched a video with white text on a dark background describing how to complete the study. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to adopt a vegetarian diet.

intervention_description: Students were exposed to a classroom education intervention aiming to reduce animal product consumption. Students saw one of five different presentations with differing focuses, and they answered a survey.
control_description: Students answered an online survey before being exposed to the classroom presentation. This set of students would act as a control group, against which the responses of the treatment group could be compared.

intervention_description: Participants watched a healthcare documentary film titled "Forks over Knives," which advocates for a plant-based diet, during a regularly scheduled course meeting in week 5 of the semester.
The vegetarian dish at the top of the menu was highlighted with a box and captioned “Chef's Recommendation”
control_description: The original menu with the vegetarian dishes appearing in the first and last place in the list

intervention_description: The name of the vegetarian dish at the top of the menu was changed from “Risotto primavera” to “Fresh seasonal risotto primavera”
control_description: The original menu with the vegetarian dishes appearing in the first and last place in the list

intervention_description: The two vegetarian options were placed together at the bottom of the menu under a line and the heading “Vegetarian Dishes”
control_description: The original menu with the vegetarian dishes appearing in the first and last place in the list

intervention_description: Participants saw four menus that included a meat option, a vegetarian option, and a decoy vegetarian option (it is 2 GBP more expensive than the other two items)
control_description: Participants saw four menus that included a meat option, a vegetarian option, and another vegetarian option, all of the same price

intervention_description: Participants saw seven menus that included a meat option, a vegetarian option, and a decoy vegetarian option (it is 2 GBP more expensive than the other two items)
control_description: Participants saw seven menus that included a meat option, a vegetarian option, and another vegetarian option, all of the same price

intervention_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the beans burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a beef burger? This is also possible on request.”
control_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the beef burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a beans burger? This is also possible on request.”

intervention_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the seaweed burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a beef burger? This is also possible on request.”
control_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the beef burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a seaweed burger? This is also possible on request.”

intervention_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the beans burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a beef burger? This is also possible on request.”
control_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the beef burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a beans burger? This is also possible on request.”

intervention_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the seaweed burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a beef burger? This is also possible on request.”
control_description: Participants saw a restaurant menu with the beef burger as the default option, but in a separate box next to it: “Rather have a seaweed burger? This is also possible on request.”

intervention_description: Participants read footprint information about the footprint of the entire US beef industry, e.g. “Every day, the beef industry in the US has a water footprint of approximately 128 billion gallons of water. To put this in perspective, 128 billion is more than the number of stars in the Milky Way.”
control_description: Participants did not receive any information about food and the environment and instead performed a filler task

intervention_description: Participants read foodprint information, but the same numerical information was scaled to the individual level and adjusted for a single individual, e.g. “A single beef burger, for example, has a water footprint of approximately 450 gallons of water. To put this in perspective, 450 gallons is more than what an average person drinks in two years.”
control_description: Participants did not receive any information about food and the environment and instead performed a filler task

intervention_description: Participants saw menu options without any labels; the choice questions differ in the types of options compared (i.e. vegetarian vs vegan vs has meat)
control_description: Participants saw menu options with a "(vegan)" or "(vegetarian)" label shown in the title of option 1; the choice questions differ in the types of options compared (i.e. vegetarian vs vegan vs has meat)

intervention_description: A survey of pre-validated measures was administered following exposure to the campaign to assess change in: fruit and vegetable intake, intentions, attitudes, perceived behavioral control, and subjective norms
control_description: A survey of pre-validated measures was administered prior to, and following exposure to the campaign to assess change in: fruit and vegetable intake, intentions, attitudes, perceived behavioral control, and subjective norms

intervention_description: Participants saw a meat option with a pictorial and textual warning label that eating meat contributes to poor health
Participants saw a meat option with a pictorial and textual warning label that eating meat contributes to climate change
Participants saw a meat option with a pictorial and textual warning label that eating meat contributes to pandemics
Control group were not provided any information prior to their bidding.
control_description: Treatment group was presented with information regarding the health and environmental benefits of consuming a plant-based meat substitute versus beef prior to bidding

intervention_description: Next to the meat and plant-based alternatives, there was a health message emphasizing the health benefits of consuming less meat: “To reduce your risk of diabetes by 40%, eat one less serving of meat every day"
control_description: Participants were presented with a shopping list consisting of meat and plant-based meat alternatives during an online grocery shopping task

intervention_description: Next to the meat and plant-based alternatives, there was a environment message emphasizing the environmental benefits of lower meat intake: “To reduce your environmental impact by 40%, eat one less serving of meat every day"
control_description: Participants were presented with a shopping list consisting of meat and plant-based meat alternatives during an online grocery shopping task

intervention_description: Next to the meat and plant-based alternatives, there was a combined message emphasizing both the health and environmental benefits of consuming less meat
control_description: Participants were presented with a shopping list consisting of meat and plant-based meat alternatives during an online grocery shopping task

intervention_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito, alongside a traffic light system, with a scale of 1–5, which was circled at the appropriate sustainability level for that burrito: beef burrito – unsustainable, chicken burrito – neither sustainable nor unsustainable and vegetarian burrito – sustainable
control_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito

intervention_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito, where the vegetarian burrito was presented alongside a popularity label consisting of a gold star next to the words ‘Most Popular’
control_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito

intervention_description: Participants received messages from a private chatbot every other day, focused on the environmental consequences of producing and eating meat (e.g. “If the livestock industry is reduced, the widespread deforestation, caused by the need for pastures, will be avoided”)

Participants received messages from a private chatbot every other day, focused on the environmental consequences of producing and eating meat, with the addition of information on the dynamic norm (e.g. “If the livestock industry is reduced, the widespread deforestation, caused by the need for pastures, will be avoided. To avoid deforestation, moreandmorepeoplearereducing their consumption of meat”)
intervention_mechanism: factual, origin of animal product, norms

intervention_description: Participants were asked to choose between three meals, based, respectively, on Meat balls, Veggie balls and Fish cakes. All three dishes were labelled with their names, but the Veggie balls were presented as the “dish of the day”. The vegetable-based dish was both labelled as “dish of the day”, and orally informed by foodservice employees as being the “dish of the day” in all countries with the following phrase: “Welcome! Today we have Veggie balls as dish of the day” (verbal prompt).
control_description: The three identical dishes to the intervention condition were just labelled with their names and no “dish of the day” was offered

intervention_description: Participants were asked to choose between three meals, based, respectively, on Meat balls, Veggie balls and Fish cakes. All three dishes were labelled with their names, but the Veggie balls were presented as the “dish of the day”. The vegetable-based dish was both labelled as “dish of the day”, and orally informed by foodservice employees as being the “dish of the day” in all countries with the following phrase: “Welcome! Today we have Veggie balls as dish of the day” (verbal prompt).

intervention_description: Participants were shown environmental information that originated from the companies selling these products (i.e. reduction in water use, land use, energy use and greenhouse gas emissions associated to each of the three beef alternatives compared to conventional beef)
control_description: Participants were asked to choose between lab-grown beef, plant-based meat animal-like heme protein, plant-based meat using pea protein, and farm-raised beef, with no additional information given about the products

intervention_description: Participants received a message based on advisories provided by health agencies, revealing health information about the risks and benefits of fish consumption; this was read out loud to them and they received a brochure with the same information
Participants were shown a menu with meat balls, fish cakes, and a veggie balls dish which was highlighted as the dish of the day

intervention_description: Participants received information about negative impacts of meat consumption on health (e.g. increased risk of non-communicable diseases)
control_description: Participants received information described the company that is responsible for the university canteen and included a recommendation to visit their website to get information about ongoing activities.

intervention_description: Participants received information about negative impacts of meat consumption on the environment (e.g. greenhouse gas emissions and deforestation).
control_description: Participants received information described the company that is responsible for the university canteen and included a recommendation to visit their website to get information about ongoing activities.

intervention_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which four vegan entrees were featured prominently as the default items on the menu and four common meat/poultry-based (i.e., omnivore) entrees as the opt-out items
control_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which four omnivore entrees were featured prominently as the default items on the menu and four vegan entrees as the opt-out items

intervention_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which four vegan and four omnivore entrees were featured prominently on the menu
control_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which four omnivore entrees were featured prominently as the default items on the menu and four vegan entrees as the opt-out items

control_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which four omnivore entrees were featured prominently as the default items on the menu and four vegan entrees as the opt-out items

intervention_description: Participants were presented with a menu with a vegetarian default black bean burger, with a separate box stating “Would you rather have a Classic Burger? – Ask the waiter”
control_description: Participants were presented with a menu with a meat default burger, with a separate box stating “Would you rather have a Black Bean Burger? – Ask the waiter”

intervention_description: Participants were shown both burgers on the menu, but the vegetarian burger was indulgently labeled “Flame-grilled Black Bean Burger.”
control_description: Participants were shown both burgers on the menu, but the vegetarian burger was explicitly labeled “Vegetarian Black Bean Burger”

intervention_description: Participants saw posters in the restaurant. Posters included an earth image, emphasizing there is no other planet, and a text suggesting them to eat vegetarian if they want to save the planet. Additionally, this poster indicated that for every vegetarian order there will be a tree donation to Eden reforestation projects.

Participants saw posters in the restaurant. Posters included an earth image, emphasizing there is no other planet, and a text suggesting them to eat vegetarian if they want to save the planet. Additionally, this poster indicated that for every vegetarian order there will be a money donation to the Eden reforestation projects.
Participants saw posters in the restaurant. Posters included an earth image, emphasizing there is no other planet, and a text suggesting them to eat vegetarian if they want to save the planet.
Participants saw a supermarket package for chicken breast meat that had a sticker with a confronting image of chickens in a battery cage with the text ‘Eating meat makes animals suffer'
control_description: Participants saw a supermarket package for chicken breast meat with no sticker

intervention_description: Participants saw a supermarket package for chicken breast meat that had a sticker with a confronting image of chickens in a battery cage with the text ‘Eating meat destroys the Amazon rainforest!' with a specific source (United Nations/Greenpeace/Greeneatz) and with or without information about the source
control_description: Participants saw a supermarket package for chicken breast meat with no sticker

intervention_description: To make participants to reflect on their inconsistent evaluations about meat, they were asked to describe two personally held reactions in favor of and two reactions opposed to meat consumption or vaccination in the control group.
control_description: Participants assigned to a task about an unrelated control topic (going to the cinema)

intervention_description: To make participants to reflect on their inconsistent evaluations about meat, they were asked to describe two personally held reactions in favor of and two reactions opposed to meat consumption or vaccination in the control group.
control_description: Participants assigned to a task about an unrelated control topic (going to the cinema)

intervention_description: Participants received 2–3 health-focused SMS per week for eight consecutive weeks via Textedly
Participants received 2–3 environment-focused SMS per week for eight consecutive weeks via Textedly
Carbon labeling is added next to the meals (low/medium/high CO2 emissions), with a screen explaining the labeling next to the checkout tiles
control_description: Only the price and name of the meal were visible to the patrons in the canteen

intervention_description: Participants choose between three similar meals, including one vegetarian (VeggieEat) meal and two non-vegetarian meals. In this condition VeggiEat dish was termed the ‘dish of the day’;
control_description: Participants choose between three similar meals, including one vegetarian (VeggieEat) meal and two non-vegetarian meals.

intervention_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with green low–climate impact labels on chicken, fish, or vegetarian items (positive framing); The top of each menu featured a disclosure statement explaining the label’s meaning: “This item is environmentally sustainable. It has low greenhouse gas emissions and a low contribution to climate change.”
control_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with QR code labels on all items

intervention_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with red high–climate impact labels on beef items (negative framing); “This item is not environmentally sustainable. It has high greenhouse gas emissions and a high contribution to climate change”
control_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with QR code labels on all items

control_description: Participants are shown a restaurant menu in which two vegetarian dishes are listed under the title of vegetarian, this section was either at the top or down of the menu.

intervention_description: The target dish had an explicit vegan label "Vegan curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes"
control_description: The target dish had a neutral label "Curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes*", with a footnote mentioning that it's also suitable for vegetarians

intervention_description: The target dish had an explicit vegetarian label "Vegetarian curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes"
control_description: The target dish had a neutral label "Curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes*", with a footnote mentioning that it's also suitable for vegetarians

intervention_description: The target dish had an explicit plant-based label "Plant-based curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes"
control_description: The target dish had a neutral label "Curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes*", with a footnote mentioning that it's also suitable for vegetarians

intervention_description: The target dish had an explicit meat-free label "Meat-free curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes"
control_description: The target dish had a neutral label "Curry stew with coconut and sweet potatoes*", with a footnote mentioning that it's also suitable for vegetarians

intervention_description: Participants participated in a 6-week cooking class in which they observed the preparation of a plant-based, olive oil diet meal and got to taste test; While the recipe was being prepared, the staff discussed consistent themes each week, including the health benefits of extra virgin olive oil and encouraging the participants to use olive oil to cook their vegetables; meat/poultry/seafood is not needed daily; vegetables and all starch products (including beans) contain protein. No other nutrition- or food-related information was provided. All of the recipes were made with extra virgin olive oil (1 to 2 tablespoons), contained on average 2 servings of vegetables, and did not contain meat/poultry or seafood
Participants received a registration presenting a vegetarian buffet as the default, allowing the active choice of a non-vegetarian option
control_description: Participants received a standard lunch registration presenting a non-vegetarian buffet as the default, but allowing the active choice of a vegetarian option

intervention_description: Participants received a registration presenting a vegetarian buffet as the default, allowing the active choice of a non-vegetarian option
control_description: Participants received a standard lunch registration presenting a non-vegetarian buffet as the default, but allowing the active choice of a vegetarian option

control_description: Participants received a standard lunch registration presenting a non-vegetarian buffet as the default, but allowing the active choice of a vegetarian option

intervention_description: Participants viewed red-meat–reduction messages linking red meat consumption with animal welfare
control_description: Participants viewed a control message encouraging reading (a neutral topic unrelated to red meat)

intervention_description: Participants viewed red-meat–reduction messages linking red meat consumption with health
control_description: Participants viewed a control message encouraging reading (a neutral topic unrelated to red meat)

intervention_description: Participants viewed red-meat–reduction messages linking red meat consumption with environmental consequences
control_description: Participants viewed a control message encouraging reading (a neutral topic unrelated to red meat)

intervention_description: Participants saw descriptive social norm message e.g. “Between 2010 and 2017, the share of vegetarian and vegan meals in our sales rose from about 24% to more than 35%.” in between a series of menu choices
control_description: Participants saw attentional control messages e.g. “All side dishes in our canteens are either vegetarian or vegan." in between a series of menu choices

intervention_description: Participants saw attentional control messages e.g. “All side dishes in our canteens are either vegetarian or vegan." in between trials of meal selections from menus
control_description: Participants saw neutral control messages e.g. "There are about 400 people employed at Studentenwerk Göttingen." in between trials of meal selections from menus

intervention_description: Participants saw descriptive social norm message e.g. “Between 2010 and 2017, the share of vegetarian and vegan meals in our sales rose from about 24% to more than 35%.” in trials of meal selection from menus
control_description: Participants saw neutral control messages e.g. "There are about 400 people employed at Studentenwerk Göttingen." in between trials of meal selections from menus

intervention_description: Participants are presented with a 120-word message designed to encompass four distinct motivational factors. In this condition, the message is specifically framed around the theme of animal welfare. (e.g. positive outcomes for animal welfare)
control_description: No message - control condition.

intervention_description: Participants are presented with a 120-word message designed to encompass four distinct motivational factors. In this condition, the message is specifically framed around the theme of environment. (e.g. positive outcomes for the environment)
control_description: No message - control condition.

intervention_description: Participants are presented with a 120-word message designed to encompass four distinct motivational factors. In this condition, the message is specifically framed around the theme of health. (positive outcomes for the health)
control_description: No message - control condition.

intervention_description: Participants are presented with a 120-word message designed to encompass four distinct motivational factors. In this condition, the message is specifically framed around the theme of social. (e.g. positive outcomes about social life, conformity, peers, belonging)
control_description: No message - control condition.

intervention_description: Every day at 9:30 and for 14 days (between T1 and T2), participants received one message per day, focused on the lower environmental impact of cultivating legumes than producing meat (e.g., “Compared to livestock feeding production, legume cultivation requires a limited use of fertilizers. Thus, it has a lower pollution impact. If you eat legumes rather than meat, you protect the planet from pollution”)
control_description: Participants did not receive any messages

intervention_description: Every day at 9:30 and for 14 days (between T1 and T2), participants received replacement messages combined with a reference to the dynamic norm (e.g., “Nowadays, more and more people eat legumes instead of meat. Compared to livestock feeding production, legume cultivation requires limited use of fertilizers. Thus, it has a low pollution impact. If you also eat legumes instead of meat, you protect the planet from pollution”).
control_description: Participants did not receive any messages

intervention_description: Participants watched a video-documentary about the environmental impact of meat production, Cowspiracy, and filled in a questionnaire pre and post-documentary
control_description: Participants watched the nature documentary, “Planet Earth” (2006) about environmental change, where no reference to meat consumption was made, and filled in a questionnaire pre and post-documentary

intervention_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented with an eco-score label, which evaluated the overall environmental impact of the products with a letter from A to E and a color from green to red, to make a meal
control_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented without any labels to make a meal

intervention_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented with a nutri-score label, which evaluated the overall nutritional score of the products with a letter from A to E and a color from green to red, to make a meal
control_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented without any labels to make a meal

intervention_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented with an eco-score label, which evaluated the overall environmental impact of the products with a letter from A to E and a color from green to red, to make a meal
control_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented without any labels to make a meal

intervention_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented with a nutri-score label, which evaluated the overall nutritional score of the products with a letter from A to E and a color from green to red, to make a meal
control_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented without any labels to make a meal

intervention_description: The reductive eco label displayed four sustainability values, i.e., the water use (in liters), the carbon footprint (in grams), the land use (in m2/year), and the nitrogen (in grams) per 100 grams of a food product.
control_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented without any labels to make a meal

intervention_description: The reductive version of the nutrition label similarly presented four nutritional values, i.e., the energy (in calories) and the amount of saturated fats (in grams), sugar (in grams), and salt (in grams) per 100 g of that product.
control_description: Participants had to choose from products that were presented without any labels to make a meal

intervention_description: Two groups of households received tailored energy-saving information, including details about global warming and energy costs, plus a personalized list of relevant energy-saving measures. Both groups were asked to achieve a 5% energy reduction and received individual feedback via a website showing their percentage energy savings, the contribution of each behavior, and money saved. The first group received only individual goals and feedback, while the second group also received a collective 5% group goal and monthly feedback about the group's average and total energy savings via newsletter.

Regular supplies of soya foods were given free-of-charge to the intervention group. Based on individual preferences, the study dietitian made speciﬁc suggestions on how to incorporate soya foods into the daily menu, such as replacing meat with tofu in stew or fried dishes, cow milk with soyamilk, and cookies with a soya protein bar. To avoid weight gain, replacing other foods was emphasized over adding soya foods. To maintain compliance, all participants received individual dietary counselling by a registered dietitian and follow-up phone calls. They had at least six contacts with the dietitian during the ﬁrst year and were counselled on how to maintain a healthy diet according to the food guide pyramid.
control_description: Women in the control group had, like in the experimental group, at least six contacts with the dietitian during the ﬁrst year and were counselled on how to maintain a healthy diet according to the food guide pyramid.

intervention_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which vegetarian option was enhanced using an appealing, taste, description;
control_description: Participants were presented with a standard menu

intervention_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which vegetarian option labeled as “chef’s favorite”
control_description: Participants were presented with a standard menu

intervention_description: Participants were presented with a menu in which a stand-out box was placed around the vegetarian option
control_description: Participants were presented with a standard menu

intervention_description: Sofritas and veggie options were kept, and a fictional PMA designated “chick’nitas” was added, giving participants three non meat options including two PMAs
control_description: The online Chipotle menu (August 2024) was duplicated, and participants had the same two non-meat options avaliable to real Chipotle diners.
